After shaking stops, check for injuries and damage
Listen to emergency broadcasts for instructions
Be prepared for aftershocks
Turn off gas if you smell it or suspect a leak
Use stairs, not elevators when evacuating buildings
Keep emergency supplies ready: water, food, first aid kit, flashlight
Have a family communication plan
Secure heavy furniture and appliances to walls before earthquakes
Practice earthquake drills regularly with family
Keep a whistle to signal rescuers if trapped
Wear sturdy shoes to protect feet from broken glass
Check water, gas, and electric lines for damage
Keep important documents in earthquake-proof container
Stock at least 3-day supply of water (1 gallon per person per day)
Have battery-powered or hand-crank radio
Learn how to shut off utilities at main valves
Identify safe spots in each room (under sturdy table, against inside wall)
donts: Don't run outside during shaking - most injuries occur from falling objects
Don't use elevators during or after an earthquake
Don't light matches or use lighters if gas leak is suspected
Don't use your phone except for emergencies - keep lines clear
Don't spread or believe rumors - rely on official sources only
Don't enter damaged buildings
Don't touch downed power lines or objects touching them
Don't use your vehicle unless absolutely necessary
Don't panic - stay calm and think clearly
Don't stand near unstable structures or debris
Don't use candles or open flames after an earthquake
Don't flush toilets if sewage lines may be damaged
Don't eat food from opened containers near broken glass
Don't go sightseeing in damaged areas
Don't leave children or pets alone after earthquake
Don't ignore evacuation orders from authorities
Don't overload electrical outlets after power restoration
Don't drink water that may be contaminated
Don't move seriously injured persons unless they're in immediate danger
Don't assume it's over after the first shake - expect aftershocks

specific_situations.indoors: Drop to ground, take cover under sturdy table, hold on until shaking stops. Stay away from windows and outside walls.
specific_situations.outdoors: Move away from buildings, trees, streetlights, and power lines. Drop to ground and stay there until shaking stops.
specific_situations.in_vehicle: Pull over to clear location away from buildings, trees, overpasses. Stay inside with seatbelt on. Don't drive over bridges or ramps that may be damaged.
specific_situations.in_bed: Stay in bed and cover your head with pillow. You're less likely to be injured by flying debris if you stay put.
specific_situations.in_stadium: Stay in your seat and protect head with arms. Don't rush for exits - wait until shaking stops.
specific_situations.trapped_under_debris: Don't light matches. Don't move or kick up dust. Cover mouth with cloth. Tap on pipes or walls. Use whistle if available.
specific_situations.near_ocean: Move to higher ground immediately after shaking - tsunami may follow. Don't return to coast until all-clear given.
specific_situations.in_wheelchair: Lock wheels, cover head and neck. If possible, move away from windows and shelves. Stay in wheelchair.
specific_situations.in_elevator: If shaking starts, push all floor buttons. Get out at first stop. Take stairs, not elevator. If trapped, call for help.
specific_situations.in_store: Move away from aisles where items could fall. Take cover under sturdy furniture or in doorway. Don't rush to exits.

preparation: Secure water heaters and gas appliances with flexible connections
Install strong latches on cabinets
Place heavy items on lower shelves
Bolt bookcases and file cabinets to wall studs
Have earthquake insurance if in seismic zone
Create family emergency communication plan with out-of-state contact
Teach all family members how to turn off gas, water, electricity
Keep fire extinguisher and know how to use it
Maintain emergency supply kit in accessible location
Know safest spots in each room of your home
aftermath: Expect aftershocks - they can be strong and cause additional damage
Check yourself and others for injuries
Inspect home for cracks, damage before entering
Clean up spilled medicines, bleach, gasoline immediately
Open cabinets cautiously - contents may fall
Check gas, electric, and water lines for damage
Document property damage with photos for insurance
Contact insurance agent to file claim
Register with disaster relief services if needed
Help neighbors who may need assistance, especially elderly or disabled

Keep car fuel tank full during flood season

Consider building walls or barriers around your property

Don't touch electrical equipment if wet or standing in water
Don't eat food that has been in contact with floodwater

specific_situations.flash_flood_warning: Take immediate action. Flash floods are extremely dangerous. Abandon vehicle if trapped. Climb to high ground.
specific_situations.in_vehicle: Turn around, don't drown. Don't drive through flooded roads. If car stalls, abandon it immediately and move to higher ground.
specific_situations.basement_flooding: Don't enter until power is shut off. Pump water slowly to prevent structural damage. Wear rubber boots and gloves.
specific_situations.contaminated_water: Boil water for 1 minute before drinking. Use bleach to disinfect (8 drops per gallon). Don't use contaminated water for brushing teeth.
specific_situations.rapid_rise_water: Don't wait for official warning. If water is rising rapidly, go to highest floor or roof. Signal for help.
specific_situations.after_flood: Don't enter building until declared safe. Check for structural damage. Document damage with photos. Begin drying within 24-48 hours to prevent mold.
specific_situations.urban_flooding: Storm drains may overflow. Underground parking floods quickly. Elevators can become death traps. Move to higher floors.
specific_situations.coastal_flooding: Storm surge can arrive before hurricane. Move inland, not just to higher floors. Don't return until all-clear signal.
specific_situations.river_flooding: Water rises more predictably than flash floods. Still deadly. Evacuate when told. Don't attempt to cross flowing streams.
specific_situations.mudslide_risk: Saturated ground on slopes can give way. Listen for rumbling sounds. Move perpendicular to mudslide path if possible.

preparation: Know your flood zone and evacuation routes
Keep sump pump maintained with backup power
Install water sensors in basement and crawl spaces
Grade landscaping away from foundation
Install backflow valves in building sewer lines
Keep sandbags, plywood, plastic sheeting available
Elevate utilities and appliances above potential flood levels
Anchor fuel tanks to prevent flotation
Review and understand flood insurance policy
Create digital copies of important documents
health_risks: Electrical hazards from downed power lines

Use a fire extinguisher only if you're trained and the fire is small
Install smoke alarms on every level and in bedrooms
Test smoke alarms monthly and replace batteries yearly
Plan and practice two escape routes from every room
Keep bedroom doors closed at night for protection
Store flammable materials properly away from heat sources
Have fire extinguisher accessible in kitchen and garage
Install fire sprinklers in your home if possible
Keep emergency ladder for upper floors
Teach children how to escape and not to hide
Have working flashlights in easily accessible locations
donts: Don't go back inside for any reason once you've evacuated
Don't try to fight a large fire yourself
Don't open doors without checking if they're hot first

Don't waste time gathering belongings

Don't overload electrical outlets or extension cords
Don't leave cooking unattended

Don't store gasoline or propane indoors
Don't block fire exits or escape routes
Don't use damaged electrical cords or appliances
Don't leave candles unattended
Don't ignore strange electrical smells or sparks
Don't delay evacuation to investigate fire source

specific_situations.kitchen_fire: If fire in pan, slide lid over it. Turn off burner. Don't move pan. Don't use water on grease fire. Use fire extinguisher if trained.
specific_situations.electrical_fire: Never use water. Turn off power if safe. Use Class C fire extinguisher. Call 911 immediately.
specific_situations.clothing_fire: Stop immediately. Drop to ground. Roll back and forth to smother flames. Cover face with hands. Cool burns with water.
specific_situations.trapped_in_room: Close door. Seal cracks with clothing or towels. Signal from window. Call 911 and tell them your location. Stay low where air is clearer.
specific_situations.smoke_filled_building: Crawl low under smoke. Cover nose and mouth with wet cloth if possible. Feel doors before opening. Take alternate route if door is hot.
specific_situations.apartment_fire: Alert neighbors. Close your door. Use stairs, not elevator. If you can't exit, seal door and call for help from window.
specific_situations.wildfire_approaching: Evacuate early. Don't wait for orders. Close all windows and doors. Remove flammable materials from around house. Bring pets inside or evacuate with them.
specific_situations.office_fire: Know locations of fire alarms and exits. Alert others. Use nearest safe exit. Assist those who need help. Go to assembly point.
specific_situations.vehicle_fire: Pull over safely. Turn off engine. Get everyone out. Move 100+ feet away. Call 911. Don't open hood if fire in engine compartment.
specific_situations.holiday_fire: Water Christmas tree daily. Keep away from heat. Turn off lights when leaving. Use LED lights. Don't burn wrapping paper in fireplace.

fire_types.class_a: Ordinary combustibles (wood, paper, cloth). Use water or ABC extinguisher.
fire_types.class_b: Flammable liquids (gasoline, oil, grease). Don't use water. Use foam or ABC extinguisher.
fire_types.class_c: Electrical fires. Turn off power first. Use CO2 or ABC extinguisher. Never use water.
fire_types.class_d: Metal fires. Use Class D extinguisher designed for specific metal.
fire_types.class_k: Kitchen fires (cooking oils, fats). Use Class K extinguisher or baking soda for small fires.

fire_extinguisher_use.pass_method: Pull pin, Aim at base of fire, Squeeze handle, Sweep side to side
fire_extinguisher_use.when_to_use: Only if fire is small, contained, not spreading rapidly, and you have clear escape route
fire_extinguisher_use.when_not_to_use: If fire is large, spreading, smoke-filled room, or you're not trained
fire_extinguisher_use.maintenance: Check pressure gauge monthly. Inspect for damage. Professional service annually.

smoke_inhalation: Smoke is the leading cause of fire deaths
Get low and go - cleaner air is near floor
Hold breath when moving through smoke if possible
Cover nose and mouth with damp cloth
Seek medical attention after any smoke exposure
Symptoms: coughing, difficulty breathing, confusion, loss of consciousness
Carbon monoxide poisoning risk - odorless and deadly
Any smoke inhalation requires medical evaluation

categories.category_1: 74-95 mph winds. Very dangerous winds causing some damage. Power outages. Minor roof damage.
categories.category_2: 96-110 mph winds. Extremely dangerous winds. Major roof and siding damage. Power outages for days to weeks.
categories.category_3: 111-129 mph winds. Devastating damage. Roof decking damage. Many trees snapped. Power and water outages for weeks.
categories.category_4: 130-156 mph winds. Catastrophic damage. Roof structures destroyed. Most trees snapped. Long-term power outages.
categories.category_5: 157+ mph winds. Catastrophic damage. Total roof failure. Complete destruction of homes. Area uninhabitable for weeks to months.

storm_surge.danger: Storm surge is often the greatest threat. It's an abnormal rise of water generated by storm's winds.
storm_surge.impact: Can reach heights of 20+ feet and extend inland for miles. Causes catastrophic damage and drowning deaths.
storm_surge.warning_signs: Rapidly rising water, especially in coastal areas. Don't wait to see it - evacuate when ordered.
storm_surge.safety: Evacuate from storm surge zones. Move inland, not just to higher floors. Water can rise rapidly.
storm_surge.after_surge: Don't return until authorities declare it safe. Floodwater may be contaminated. Roads may be damaged.

preparation_timeline.36_hours_before: Review plans. Check supplies. Charge devices. Monitor forecasts. Secure outdoor items.
preparation_timeline.24_hours_before: Evacuate if ordered. Fill gas tank. Get cash. Stock up on supplies. Board windows.
preparation_timeline.12_hours_before: Turn fridge to coldest. Fill bathtubs with water. Locate safe room. Stay indoors. Continuous monitoring.
preparation_timeline.6_hours_before: Final preparations. Move to safe room. Keep family together. Emergency supplies accessible.
preparation_timeline.during_storm: Stay inside. Away from windows. Listen to updates. Don't go out during eye. Wait for all-clear.

after_hurricane: Don't return home until authorities say it's safe
Watch for downed power lines and flooding
Document damage with photos for insurance
Check for gas leaks, structural damage before entering home

specific_locations.home_with_basement: Go to basement immediately. Get under workbench or stairs. Avoid areas under heavy objects on floor above.
specific_locations.home_no_basement: Go to interior room on lowest floor (bathroom, closet, hallway). Get in bathtub if possible. Cover with mattress.
specific_locations.mobile_home: LEAVE IMMEDIATELY. Go to designated shelter or permanent structure. If no shelter, lie flat in ditch and cover head.
specific_locations.school: Go to designated shelter area. Interior hallway on lowest floor. Crouch low and cover head. Stay away from gymnasiums and cafeterias.
specific_locations.office_building: Go to interior rooms, hallways on lowest floor. Stay away from windows and elevators. Get under desk or table.
specific_locations.shopping_mall: Move to interior small shops or storage rooms. Avoid large open spaces. Get low and protect head.
specific_locations.vehicle: If possible, drive to nearest sturdy shelter. If tornado is close, abandon vehicle and lie flat in ditch. Don't shelter under overpass.
specific_locations.outdoors: Seek lowest ground available (ditch, ravine). Lie flat and cover head with hands. Watch for flash flooding.
specific_locations.church: Avoid large spaces with wide-span roofs. Go to interior rooms or hallways if possible. Get under pews if no other option.
specific_locations.high_rise: Can't reach lowest floor? Go to interior stairwell or small room on lowest floor accessible. Stay away from windows.

Loud roar similar to freight train

frostbite.symptoms: Numbness, white or grayish-yellow skin, unusually firm or waxy skin
frostbite.areas_affected: Fingers, toes, nose, ears, cheeks, chin most vulnerable
frostbite.treatment: Get to warm place. Immerse in warm (not hot) water. Don't rub affected area. Seek medical attention.
frostbite.prevention: Dress in layers. Cover all exposed skin. Keep dry. Take breaks from cold. Watch for symptoms.

hypothermia.symptoms: Shivering, exhaustion, confusion, fumbling hands, memory loss, slurred speech, drowsiness
hypothermia.danger: Life-threatening. Body temperature drops below 95°F. Can cause death.
hypothermia.treatment: Get to warm place. Remove wet clothing. Warm center of body first. Give warm beverages if conscious. Seek medical help immediately.
hypothermia.prevention: Stay dry. Dress in layers. Eat adequately. Avoid alcohol. Stay active but don't overexert.

frozen_pipes.prevention: Insulate pipes. Keep cabinet doors open. Let faucets drip. Maintain temperature above 55°F even when away.
frozen_pipes.signs: Little or no water flow. Frost on pipes. Strange odors from drains.
frozen_pipes.action: Keep faucet open. Apply heat to frozen section (hair dryer, heating pad). Never use open flame. Call plumber if can't locate or thaw.
frozen_pipes.burst_pipe: Shut off main water valve immediately. Call plumber. Document damage for insurance.

natural_warning_signs: Strong earthquake lasting 20 seconds or more near coast
Rapid rise or fall of coastal waters
Ocean receding dramatically, exposing sea floor
Strong current or rapid tide change
Ground shaking that makes it hard to stand

evacuation.immediate_action: Drop your belongings. Move immediately to high ground or inland.
evacuation.on_foot: Often fastest method. Know walking evacuation routes. Head uphill perpendicular to shore.
evacuation.by_vehicle: Only if clear route to high ground. Don't get stuck in traffic. Be prepared to abandon vehicle and run.
evacuation.vertical_evacuation: If can't reach high ground, go to upper floors of reinforced concrete building as last resort.
evacuation.after_first_wave: Don't return. Subsequent waves may be larger. Stay in safe area for hours after last wave.
evacuation.with_pets: Take if immediately available. Don't delay evacuation searching for pets.
evacuation.assist_others: Help those who need assistance if possible without delaying your evacuation.
evacuation.assembly_points: Know designated gathering areas. Report to authorities that you're safe.

zones.red_zone: Highest risk. Immediate evacuation required. Within minutes of wave arrival after earthquake.
zones.orange_zone: High risk. Evacuate quickly. 10-30 minutes potential warning time.
zones.yellow_zone: Moderate risk. Be prepared to evacuate. May have 30+ minutes warning time.
zones.inundation_zone: Area potentially affected by tsunami. Know if you live/work in this zone.

heat_illness.heat_cramps: Symptoms: Muscle pain, spasms. Treatment: Stop activity, drink water, rest in cool place.
heat_illness.heat_exhaustion: Symptoms: Heavy sweating, weakness, cold/clammy skin, fast pulse, nausea. Treatment: Move to cool place, loosen clothes, sip water, cool with wet cloths. Seek medical help if symptoms worsen.
heat_illness.heat_stroke: Symptoms: High body temp (103°F+), hot/dry skin, rapid pulse, confusion, unconsciousness. LIFE-THREATENING. Call 911 immediately. Move to cool place, cool with whatever available, don't give fluids.
